newsitem.title: UK: Sage shares fall as profit growth slows.
newsitem.headline: Sage shares fall as profit growth slows.

text.p: Shares in software seller Sage Group Plc fell on Wednesday despite a 20 percent increase in first-half profits.
The shares were 12-1/2p lower at 640p by 0842 GMT after earlier sinking as low as 620p. Volume was a relatively thin 99,000 shares.
Traders said the slump in the share price was in response to a slowdown in profits growth "because Sage has done marvellously well in the past".
"There's slight disappointment," one dealer said. "The shares tend to overreact."

Sage reported first-half profits of 19.3 million stg up 20 percent from 16.1 million stg a year ago. The company said foreign exchange movements had affected turnover by 5.5 million stg and pretax profit by 1.1 million stg.
Turnover improved by two percent in the first six months to 73.6 million stg.
During the last full-year period to September 96, pre-tax profits at the company grew by 28.6 percent, a decline from 63 percent growth the previous year.
Chairman, David Goldman said on Wednesday, "The second half has started well and I expect that the outcome for the full year will be entirely satisfactory."
During the last twelve months shares in Sage have outperformed the rest of the sector by 18 percent and the FTSE-All-Share index by 27 percent.
